div.l: ¶ Here begynnyth the Cokis tale
A Prentise whylom̄ dwelt in our̉e Cete
Of a Craft of vitelers was he
As gaylard he was as goldsmyth in þe shawe
Broun̄ as a bery a propir short felawe
With lokkis blake I kembit ful fetously
Daunce he coude right wele and Iolely
That he was clepid Perkyn̄ revelour̉e
He was as ful of love and Paramour̉e
As is the hyve ful of hony swete
Wel was þe wench that wᵗith hym̄ myght slepe
At every bridal wol he syng and hop
He lovid bett̉ir þe nevir þan the Shop̄
For when ther̉e ony riding was in Chepe
Out of þe shop thidir wold he lepe
Til that he had al the sight I seyn̄
And daunsid wele he wold nat com ageyn̄
And gadrid hym a meyne of his sort
To hop and syng and makyn̄ such disport
And ther̉e they set stevyn̄ for to mete
To pley atte Dise in such astrete
For in the Town̄ was ther̉e non̄ prentise
That feirer coud cast a peir̉e of dise
Than Perkyn̄ coude and ther̉e to he was fre
Of his dispensis in plase of pryvite
That fond his mastir wele in his chaffare
For oft tym̄ he fond his boxe ful bare
For sothly a prentise that is a revelour̉e
That hauntith dise ryot and paramour̉e
His Mastir shal it in his shop aby
Al have he no part of þe mynstralsy
For theft and ryot þey ben̄ convertibil
Al can he pley on̄ gitern̄ or ribibil
Revel and trowith as in alowe degre
They ben̄ ful vroith al day as men may se
This Ioly Prentise with his mastir stode
Til he was nere out of his prentishode
Al wer̉e he stubbid both erly and late
